variant.question: After landing, in case of high temperature of the brakes you:

options.text: release the parking brake and you approach the wheels either from aft or fore.
release the parking brake and you approach the wheels sidewards.
apply the parking brake and you approach the wheels either from fore or aft.
apply the parking brake and approach the wheels sidewards.

variant.question:
An Operator has a fleet of jet aeroplanes of one type. Some aeroplanes have steel brakes and others carbon brakes. How might the taxi procedures for the two variants vary?
The aeroplanes with steel brakes should be taxied at a:

options.text: Lower speed using frequent, short brake applications, whereas the aeroplanes with carbon brakes should be left to accelerate to a higher taxi speed before slowing right down to limit the number of brake applications.

Lower speed by keeping the brakes gently applied to minimise the number of applications; the aeroplane with carbon brakes should be allowed to accelerate to a higher speed prior to keeping the brakes gently applied to then maintain a constant taxi speed.

Constant speed with the application of prolonged braking to gently allow the brakes to warm up to their optimum operating temperature; the aeroplanes with carbon brakes should have their taxi speed controlled by frequent, short brake applications.

Speed where the use of the brakes is kept to an absolute minimum in order to prevent brake fade; a similar procedure should be used for the aeroplanes with carbon brakes to prevent the brakes from overheating and oxidising.

variant.question: What is recommended to do to enhance brake life in relation to brake wear?

options.text: For steel brakes - use a large number of small brake applications during taxi.
For both carbon and steel brakes - use differential braking to reduce brake temperatures.
For steel brakes - use a single, firm brake application during taxi.
For carbon brakes - use a large number of small brake applications during taxi.

variant.question: The Pilot-in-Command has just rejected a take-off in a transport category aircraft close to its maximum take-off mass. The rejection was made around 60 knots Indicated Airspeed due to a blocked runway. Prior to attempting another take-off, as regards the aircraft tyres and brakes, what should the flight crew consider and do?

options.text: Calculate and wait for the expiry of the brake cooling time before attempting a subsequent take-off.
ATC should be asked for the required brake cooling time before attempting a subsequent take-off.
If the aircraft has carbon brakes NO cooling time is required, and a subsequent takeoff may be performed immediately.
If the tyres did NOT ignite or explode immediately after rejection a subsequent takeoff may be performed immediately.

variant.question: A pilot is taxying out for take-off in a very hot day. The aircraft is equipped with carbon brakes. The pilot is aware that it is going to be a long taxi and wants to maximise the brakes' ability to absorb energy in case of a rejected take-off. Therefore, to control the taxxi speed, he / she decides to use....

options.text: firm brake applications, as carbon-brake wear is determined by the number of times the brakes are applied.
frequent light brake applications, as carbon-brake wear is determined by the brakes' temperature.
frequent light brake applications, as carbon-brake wear is determined by the number of times the brakes are applied.
firm brake applications, as carbon-brake wear is determined by the brakes' temperature.

variant.question: Due to a risk of tyre explosions when the brakes are very hot, the landing gear should be approached:

options.text: either from the front or the rear.
from the outboard side.
from any direction.
from the inboard side.

variant.question: One of the correct actions to take in the case of overheated brakes after landing or an aborted take-off is to....

options.text: consider where to park the aircraft as regards proximity to other aircraft, buildings, etc.
keep the aeroplane on the runway for as long as possible.
pour water on the heated brakes to cool them.
set the parking brake and approach the main landing gear from the sides.

variant.question: One of the correct actions to take in the case of overheated brakes after landing or an aborted take-off is to

options.text: consider where to park the aircraft as regards proximity to other aircraft, buildings, etc..
set the parking brake and approach the main landing gear from the sides.
pour water on the heated brakes to cool them.
keep the aeroplane on the runway for as long as possible.

variant.question: One of the correct actions to take in the case of overheated brakes after landing or an aborted take-off is to..

options.text: consider where to park the aircraft as regards proximity to other aircraft, buildings, etc..
pour water on the heated brakes to cool them.
keep the aeroplane on the runway for as long as possible.
set the parking brake and approach the main landing gear from the sides.

variant.question: In general, what is one of your initial actions after a high-speed aborted take-off with overheated brakes?

options.text: You give consideration to appropriate parking area.
You set the parking brake after coming to a complete stop.
You should always remain on the runway until fire assistance arrives.
You inform the ground personnel to approach the tyres from the side.

variant.question: How should a hot brake/tire fire be extinguished?

options.text: Sand or dry powder.
Hot water vapour must not be used due to quick cooling which may cause a tyre to explode.
CO~2~ for quick cooling.
Water spray.

variant.question: The braking efficiency is a piece of information presenting itself in the form of a:

options.text: combination of the terms: poor, medium, good.
letter falling between A and E.
percentage varying from 10% to 100%.
zero followed by two decimals.

variant.question: Which of the following statements regarding the cooling of hot brakes and wheel fires is correct?

options.text: Rapid cooling of a hot wheel may cause an explosive failure of the wheel.
Carbon dioxide is the best extinguishing agent for brake fires.
After the deflation of tyres due to fusible plugs, only dry chemical agents can be used safely.
Water fog must not be used to cool hot brakes.

variant.question: Which of the following statements regarding the cooling of hot brakes and wheel fires is correct?

options.text: Rapid cooling of a hot wheel may cause an explosive failure of the wheel.
Water fog must not be used to cool brakes.
Carbon dioxide is the best extinguishing agent for brake fires.
After the deflation of tyres due to fusible plugs, only dry chemical agents can be used safely.

variant.question: Following a landing with overweight and overspeed conditions, the tyres and brakes are extremely hot. For safety reasons, the landing gear wheels should be approached

options.text: from front or rear side.
from any side.
under no circumstances.
from left or right side.

variant.question: In the case of overheating of the brakes following the landing, the appropriate action at the parking position is: - Set parking brake on. - Set parking brake off, with chocks in position. - Spray water on the brakes. - Ventilate the brakes.
Your aircraft is equipped with steel brakes. How can the pilot maximise braking performance?

options.text: Frequent light taps on the brakes because the brakes are limited by heat.
Frequent light taps on the brakes because the brakes are limited by the amount of times brakes are pressed.
Few firm taps on the brakes because the brakes are limited by the amount of times brakes are pressed.
Few firm taps on the brakes because the brakes are limited by heat.

variant.question: To enhance brake life in rlation to brake wear, it is recommended.

options.text: for steel brakes to use a large number of small brake applications during taxi.
for steel brakes to use a single, firm brake application during taxi.
for carbon brakes to use a large number of small brake applications during taxi.
for both carbon and steel brakes to use diffferential braking to reduce brake temperatures.

variant.question: Your aircraft is equipped with steel brakes. During taxi, what braking technique should you apply?

options.text: Short and light braking action, since steel brakes wear due to heat.
Short and light braking action, since steel brakes wear due to number of applications.
Fewer, stronger applications, since steel brakes wear due to heat.
Fewer, stronger applications, since steel brakes wear based on number of applications.

variant.question: After a landing, with overweight and overspeed conditions, the tyres and brakes are extremely hot. The firefighters should approach the landing gear tyres:

options.text: only from front or rear side.
only from left or right side.
from any side.
under no circumstances.

variant.question: Following a high speed aborted take-off, you see a brake overheat warning. What action would be appropriate?

options.text: Stop on the taxiway, do not apply the parking brake, and notify fire services.
Remain on the runway for as long as possible.
Stop on the taxiway, apply the parking brake, and evacuate the aircraft.
Expedite taxiing to an area away from buildings and other aircraft, to reduce risk in case of a brake disc explosion.

variant.question: Your airplane uses steel brakes. How will you gain maximum performance when you taxi to the runway?

options.text: Frequent light taps because brakes limited by heat.
Few firm braking because brakes limited by times braked.
Few firm braking because brakes limited by heat.
Frequent light taps because brakes limited by times braked.

variant.question: Which of the following options correctly states the difference in operation of carbon and steel brakes?

options.text: High speed and long braking for carbon brakes.
Light and continuous braking for carbon brakes.
Constant braking to keep brakes heated for steel brakes.
Hard and as little as possible braking for steel brakes.

variant.question: An aircraft is flying from Frankfurt, Germany to Quebec, Canada. While in the NAT HLA, an in-flight emergency calls for a diversion to Keflavik, Iceland. The aircraft lands at maximum landing mass and vacates the runway. Brake temperature warnings light up. The crew becomes concerned about the possibility of a brake fire. An appropriate action would be to:

options.text: Stop on the taxiway, do NOT apply the parking brake and request the Airport Fire Service to attend.
Stop on the taxiway, apply the parking brake, request the Airport Fire Service to attend, and evacuate the aircraft.
Taxi to the Terminal where the crew can check the brakes approaching from the side to avoid injury from possible disc blowout.
Expedite taxiing to a clear area away from buildings and / or other aircraft in case of a disc blowout.

variant.question: When the brakes are overheated, you should:

options.text: Consider where to park away from buildings and other aircraft.
Stay on the runway as long as possible.
Pour water on the brakes.
When parked leave the parking brake on and only approach the wheels from the side.

variant.question: A crew are about to take-off from Paris, France to Washington, USA at the maximum Performance-Limited Take-Off Mass. Just before V1 during the take-off, a master caution indicates a serious engine malfunction. The take-off is aborted with maximum braking but without the use of reverse thrust, as soon as the aircraft stops a brake temperature warning is noted. What should the pilots do?

options.text: Stop the aircraft on the runway, do NOT apply the parking brake and request fire vehicles to attend because of the possibility of a brake fire.
Vacate the runway and stop the aircraft on the taxiway, apply the parking brake, shut down the engines and evacuate the aircraft.
Vacate the runway and expedite taxiing to the terminal area where the brakes can be properly checked for overheating.
Stop the aircraft on the runway, apply the parking brake, request a follow me truck to inspect any damage there might be to the brakes, and coaches to de-plane the passengers on the runway.

variant.question: What is the difference in operation of carbon and steel brakes?

options.text: High speed and long braking for carbon brakes.
Hard and as little as possible braking for steel brakes.
Constant braking to keep brakes heated for steel brakes.
Light and continuous braking for carbon brakes.

variant.question:
In the case of overheating of the brakes following the landing, the appropriate action at the parking position is 
1 set parking brake on 
2 set parking brake off, with chocks in position 
3 spray water on the brakes 
4 ventilate the brakes The combination regrouping of all the correct statements is?
